intro: Anaphyllopsis americana, commonly known as the American water clover, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the family Onagraceae and is characterized by its distinctive, trifoliate leaves that resemble clover. The plant typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of streams, thriving in moist, acidic soils. It produces small, white or pinkish flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Anaphyllopsis americana plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for aquatic and terrestrial wildlife.
